name: Posterior Dominant Rhythm (PDR)
age_notes: Typical adult 8–13 Hz; age-dependent in children/elderly
morphology: Sinusoidal, symmetric rhythm maximal posteriorly

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: PDR attenuates with eye opening; OIRDA is slower (1–3 Hz) and often intermittent

common_confusions.why_confused: Eye activity can contaminate posterior leads
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Eye blinks are frontally maximal and time-locked to blinking
PDR is faster (8–13 Hz) and reactive; drowsy slowing is slower (theta/delta) and state-dependent

when_concerning: Absent or poorly reactive PDR may suggest diffuse dysfunction depending on context

filters: High LFF (>0.5 Hz) may attenuate PDR; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
Low HFF may smooth fast activity
montage_effects: Reference choice can change apparent amplitude distribution
Best seen in referential montages (average reference); bipolar may show phase reversals
settings_sensitivity.sensitivity_notes: Standard sensitivity (7–10 µV/mm) adequate; too low sensitivity can hide low-amplitude rhythm

abret_exam_pearls: PDR should attenuate with eye opening; lack of reactivity may be significant in context.
PDR frequency is age-dependent; slower PDR may be normal in children.
PDR is best assessed with eyes closed and should attenuate with eye opening.

report_language.how_to_describe: Well-formed posterior dominant rhythm at 9–10 Hz, symmetric, reactive to eye opening.
avoid_saying: Normal EEG solely based on presence of PDR

name: Mu Rhythm
morphology: Arch-like, wicket-shaped rhythm
key_features: Blocks with movement or intention to move

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Mu rhythm blocks with movement; focal spikes do not. Mu is arch-shaped and rhythmic; spikes are sharp and isolated with aftergoing slow waves

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in central electrodes (C3, C4, Cz); referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Mu rhythm is central, arch-shaped, and attenuates with movement of the contralateral limb.
Mu can mimic epileptiform activity but typically lacks aftergoing slow waves.

report_language.how_to_describe: Central mu rhythm, arch-shaped, reactive to movement.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform activity when describing mu rhythm

name: Wicket Spikes
morphology: Intermittent trains of monophasic arciform waveforms or single spike-like waveforms
key_features: Intermittent trains of monophasic arciform waveforms
May occur as single spike-like waveforms
Occur exclusively on one side (left > right) or bilaterally with shifting predominance
Possibly represent fragments of temporal alpha activity or the third rhythm
Seen during wakefulness, drowsiness, and light sleep

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Wicket spikes lack aftergoing slow waves and do not disrupt background; epileptiform sharp waves have slow waves and disrupt background

common_confusions.why_confused: Both are small sharp temporal activity
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Wicket spikes occur in trains without slow waves; epileptiform spikes are isolated or in brief bursts with slow waves

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may smooth the arc shape
montage_effects: Best seen in temporal chain (F7–T3–T5 or F8–T4–T6); referential montages may show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Wicket spikes occur in trains, are arciform, and do not disrupt the background.
Absence of aftergoing slow wave supports benign wicket spikes vs epileptiform temporal spikes.
If a single spike is found, it should be compared with a train of wicket spikes on other pages to confirm identification.
Should not be mistaken for temporal seizure discharge or spikes.

report_language.how_to_describe: Temporal wicket spikes, arciform, occurring in trains, without aftergoing slow waves.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform discharges when describing wicket spikes

name: 3 Hz Generalized Spike-and-Wave
morphology: Spike followed by slow wave complexes

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: 3 Hz GSW is faster (3 Hz) and regular; slow spike-and-wave is slower (2 Hz) and irregular, associated with Lennox-Gastaut
Photic driving is time-locked to flash rate and occipital; 3 Hz GSW is generalized, frontally predominant, and not time-locked

when_concerning: Correlates with clinical absence events

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages; bipolar may show phase reversals

abret_exam_pearls: Classic 3 Hz spike-and-wave is associated with typical absence seizures; often provoked by hyperventilation.
Generalized onset and synchrony help distinguish from focal discharges.
3 Hz GSW shows abrupt onset and offset, is enhanced by hyperventilation, and correlates with clinical absence events.

report_language.how_to_describe: Generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave complexes, frontally predominant, enhanced by hyperventilation.
avoid_saying: Focal epilepsy when describing generalized spike-and-wave

name: Hypsarrhythmia
morphology: Chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Hypsarrhythmia has chaotic high-amplitude slow waves WITH multifocal spikes; diffuse slowing lacks spikes
Hypsarrhythmia is continuous chaotic pattern; multifocal spikes are discrete events

associated_with: Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) - common cause, vigabatrin is first-line for TSC-related spasms
Urgent treatment required (delayed control associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes)
First-line treatment: ACTH or high-dose corticosteroids (prednisolone), and vigabatrin (especially for tuberous sclerosis)
when_concerning: Associated with developmental regression and spasms
Requires urgent treatment as delayed control is associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes
Successful treatment indicated by cessation of spasms and resolution of hypsarrhythmia on EEG
Persistent hypsarrhythmia indicates poor prognosis

filters: Standard filters adequate; high LFF may mask slow components
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages to show diffuse nature
settings_sensitivity.sensitivity_notes: May require lower sensitivity due to high amplitude

abret_exam_pearls: Hypsarrhythmia: chaotic high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes; associated with infantile spasms.
Modified hypsarrhythmia variants exist—clinical correlation is essential.
Infantile spasms require urgent treatment (ACTH or high-dose corticosteroids, vigabatrin) as delayed control is associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes.
Successful treatment is indicated by cessation of spasms AND resolution of hypsarrhythmia on EEG. Persistent hypsarrhythmia indicates poor prognosis.
Vigabatrin requires ophthalmologic monitoring due to risk of irreversible peripheral visual field constriction.

report_language.how_to_describe: Hypsarrhythmia: chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes, more prominent in sleep.
avoid_saying: Normal infant EEG when hypsarrhythmia is present

name: Lambda Waves
morphology: Sharp, triangular positive waves

common_confusions.why_confused: Both are positive occipital sharp transients
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Lambda waves occur during visual scanning; POSTS occur during sleep
Lambda waves are positive and disappear with eye closure; epileptiform spikes are negative and persist

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in occipital electrodes (O1, O2); referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Lambda waves are positive occipital sharp transients that appear during visual scanning and disappear with eye closure. This reactivity distinguishes them from epileptiform activity.

report_language.how_to_describe: Positive occipital sharp transients (lambda waves) seen during visual scanning, reactive to eye closure.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform discharges when describing lambda waves

name: Positive Occipital Sharp Transients of Sleep (POSTS)
age_notes: Common in adults, less common in children
morphology: Sharp, positive triangular waves

common_confusions.why_confused: Both are positive occipital sharp transients
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: POSTS occur during sleep; lambda waves occur during wakefulness and visual scanning
POSTS are positive and occur during sleep; epileptiform spikes are negative and may occur in wakefulness

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in occipital electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: POSTS are positive occipital sharp transients seen during sleep. They are normal variants and should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

report_language.how_to_describe: Positive occipital sharp transients of sleep (POSTS), normal variant.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform discharges when describing POSTS

name: Rhythmic Mid-Temporal Theta Bursts of Drowsiness (RMTD)
morphology: Rhythmic bursts or trains of theta waves (5–7 Hz) usually with a notched appearance
key_features: Also known as Rhythmic Mid-Temporal Discharges (RMTD) and psychomotor variant
Composed of rhythmic bursts or trains of theta waves
Occurs bilaterally with shifting emphasis from side to side
Does not evolve into other waveforms or frequencies
Occurs during relaxed wakefulness and drowsiness

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: RMTD is rhythmic and symmetric; pathologic temporal slowing is irregular and asymmetric
RMTD is rhythmic theta; spikes are sharp and isolated

filters: Standard filters adequate; high LFF may attenuate
montage_effects: Best seen in temporal chain (T3, T4); referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: RMTD is rhythmic, symmetric, and occurs during drowsiness. It lacks the irregularity and asymmetry of pathologic temporal slowing.
RMTD is monomorphic and monorhythmic and does not evolve - this distinguishes it from epileptiform activity which shows evolution.
The notched appearance can resemble fast/slow alpha variants except that RMTD occurs over mid-temporal regions rather than posterior head regions.

report_language.how_to_describe: Rhythmic mid-temporal theta of drowsiness (RMTD), normal variant.
avoid_saying: Temporal slowing or Pathologic activity when describing RMTD

name: Benign Sporadic Sleep Spikes (BSSS) / Benign Epileptiform Transients of Sleep (BETS)
morphology: Low-voltage (<50 µV) and short-duration (<50 ms) monophasic or diphasic spike with abrupt ascending limb and steep descending limb
key_features: Also known as small sharp spikes (SSS) or benign epileptiform transients of sleep (BETS)
Seen in adults during drowsiness and light sleep
Abrupt ascending limb and steep descending limb
Usually do not have a slow-wave component
Do not occur in repetitive trains
Commonly occur unilaterally but can independently involve the opposite hemisphere

common_confusions.why_confused: Both are small sharp temporal spikes
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: BETS lack aftergoing slow waves; epileptiform spikes have slow waves
BETS are isolated small spikes; wicket spikes occur in trains

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may smooth spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in temporal chain; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: BETS are small sharp spikes that lack aftergoing slow waves. This distinguishes them from epileptiform activity.

report_language.how_to_describe: Benign epileptiform transients of sleep (BETS), normal variant.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform discharges when describing BETS

name: Vertex Sharp Waves
age_notes: Common in all ages during sleep
morphology: Sharp waves maximal at vertex

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Vertex sharp waves are normal sleep elements; central spikes are epileptiform and may occur in wakefulness

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen at vertex (Cz); referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Vertex sharp waves are normal sleep elements maximal at Cz. They are part of normal sleep architecture.

report_language.how_to_describe: Vertex sharp waves, normal sleep element.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform activity when describing vertex sharp waves

name: Sleep Spindles
age_notes: Present in normal sleep from infancy
morphology: Rhythmic 11–15 Hz activity in brief bursts

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Sleep spindles are 11–15 Hz bursts during sleep; beta is continuous and may be medication-related

when_concerning: Absent spindles may indicate sleep disruption

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate
montage_effects: Best seen in central/frontal electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Sleep spindles are 11–15 Hz rhythmic bursts seen during N2 and N3 sleep. They are normal sleep elements.

report_language.how_to_describe: Sleep spindles, 11–15 Hz, normal sleep element.
avoid_saying: Abnormal activity when describing sleep spindles

name: K-Complex
morphology: Sharp negative wave followed by positive wave

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: K-complexes are normal sleep elements; sharp wave complexes are epileptiform and may disrupt background

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in frontal/central electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: K-complexes are normal sleep elements consisting of a sharp negative wave followed by a positive wave, maximal frontally.

report_language.how_to_describe: K-complexes, normal sleep element.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform activity when describing K-complexes

name: Focal Spikes (Temporal)
age_notes: Common in all ages with temporal lobe epilepsy
morphology: Sharp waves with aftergoing slow waves

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Focal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and disrupt background; wicket spikes lack slow waves and do not disrupt background
Focal spikes have aftergoing slow waves; BETS lack slow waves

when_concerning: Correlates with seizure risk

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in temporal chain; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Focal temporal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and may disrupt background rhythm. This distinguishes them from benign variants.

report_language.how_to_describe: Focal sharp waves over the temporal region with aftergoing slow waves.
avoid_saying: Benign variant when describing epileptiform spikes

name: Focal Spikes (Frontal)
age_notes: Common in all ages with frontal lobe epilepsy
morphology: Sharp waves with aftergoing slow waves

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Frontal spikes have aftergoing slow waves; mu rhythm is arch-shaped and blocks with movement

when_concerning: Correlates with seizure risk

filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in frontal electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Frontal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and may disrupt background. They are enhanced by sleep.

report_language.how_to_describe: Focal sharp waves over the frontal region with aftergoing slow waves.
avoid_saying: Benign variant when describing epileptiform spikes

name: Diffuse Slowing
age_notes: Abnormal in alert wakefulness at any age
morphology: Slow waves (theta/delta)

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric; focal slowing is regional
Diffuse slowing persists in alert wakefulness; drowsy slowing is state-dependent

when_concerning: Indicates generalized cerebral dysfunction

filters: High LFF may mask diffuse slowing; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages

abret_exam_pearls: Diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric, indicating generalized cerebral dysfunction. It persists in alert wakefulness, unlike drowsy slowing.

report_language.how_to_describe: Diffuse slowing with theta/delta activity, bilateral and symmetric.
avoid_saying: Normal drowsy slowing when describing persistent diffuse slowing in alert wakefulness

name: Focal Slowing
morphology: Slow waves (theta/delta)

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Focal slowing is regional; diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric
Focal slowing persists in wakefulness; drowsy slowing is state-dependent

when_concerning: Indicates focal cortical dysfunction

filters: High LFF may mask focal slowing; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages; bipolar may show phase reversals

abret_exam_pearls: Focal slowing is regional and indicates focal cortical dysfunction. It persists across states, unlike drowsy slowing.

report_language.how_to_describe: Focal slowing over the [region] with theta/delta activity.
avoid_saying: Normal variant when describing persistent focal slowing

name: Frontal Intermittent Rhythmic Delta Activity (FIRDA)
morphology: Rhythmic delta activity

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: FIRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; pathologic frontal slowing is irregular and continuous

when_concerning: Indicates encephalopathy

filters: High LFF may mask FIRDA; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
montage_effects: Best seen in frontal electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: FIRDA is rhythmic, intermittent frontal delta activity. It is seen in encephalopathy and is distinct from irregular pathologic slowing.

report_language.how_to_describe: Frontal intermittent rhythmic delta activity (FIRDA), consistent with encephalopathy.
avoid_saying: Normal variant when describing FIRDA

name: Occipital Intermittent Rhythmic Delta Activity (OIRDA)
morphology: Rhythmic delta activity

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: OIRDA is slower (1–3 Hz) and intermittent; PDR is faster (8–13 Hz) and continuous
OIRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; pathologic occipital slowing is irregular and continuous

when_concerning: Indicates encephalopathy

filters: High LFF may mask OIRDA; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
montage_effects: Best seen in occipital electrodes; referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: OIRDA is rhythmic, intermittent occipital delta activity. It is more common in children and indicates encephalopathy.

report_language.how_to_describe: Occipital intermittent rhythmic delta activity (OIRDA), consistent with encephalopathy.
avoid_saying: Normal variant when describing OIRDA

name: Fast Alpha Variant
morphology: Notched appearance, twice as fast as PDR
key_features: Reactive to eye opening and closure

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Fast alpha variant is posterior and reactive to eye opening; RMTD is mid-temporal and occurs during drowsiness
Fast alpha variant is occipital; beta rhythm is frontal, central, and parietal

filters: Standard filters (LFF 1 Hz, HFF 70 Hz) adequate
High LFF may attenuate
montage_effects: Best seen in posterior referential montages

abret_exam_pearls: Fast alpha variant is a harmonic of PDR (twice as fast). It is posterior and reactive to eye opening, distinguishing it from beta rhythm (frontal/central) and RMTD (temporal).

report_language.how_to_describe: Fast alpha variant, harmonic of posterior dominant rhythm, reactive to eye opening.
avoid_saying: Beta rhythm when describing fast alpha variant

name: Slow Alpha Variant
morphology: Notched appearance, half as fast as PDR
key_features: Reactive to eye opening and closure
More difficult to discern without clear reactivity

common_confusions.why_confused: Both have notched appearance and similar frequency
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Slow alpha variant is posterior and reactive to eye opening; RMTD is mid-temporal and occurs during drowsiness
Slow alpha variant is reactive to eye opening; drowsy slowing is state-dependent and not reactive

filters: Standard filters (LFF 1 Hz, HFF 70 Hz) adequate
High LFF may attenuate
montage_effects: Best seen in posterior referential montages

abret_exam_pearls: Slow alpha variant is a harmonic of PDR (half as fast). Reactivity to eye opening and closure is key for identification. Without clear reactivity, it can be difficult to distinguish from pathologic slowing.

report_language.how_to_describe: Slow alpha variant, harmonic of posterior dominant rhythm, reactive to eye opening.
avoid_saying: Posterior slowing when describing slow alpha variant

name: Alpha Squeak
morphology: Transient increase in frequency immediately after eye closure
key_features: Occurs immediately after eye closure (first 0.5–1 s)
Should be excluded from PDR frequency assessment

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Alpha squeak is transient (first 0.5–1 s after eye closure); PDR is sustained. Exclude alpha squeak when assessing PDR frequency.

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in posterior referential montages

abret_exam_pearls: Alpha squeak is a transient frequency increase immediately after eye closure. Assessment of PDR frequency should exclude the first 0.5–1 s after eye closure to avoid overestimation.

report_language.how_to_describe: Transient frequency increase in posterior rhythm immediately after eye closure (alpha squeak), normal variant.
avoid_saying: Abnormal frequency when describing alpha squeak

name: Midline Theta Rhythm (Ciganek Rhythm)
morphology: Rhythmic train of 5–7 Hz smooth, sinusoidal, arciform, spiky, or mu-like activity
key_features: Most prominent in central vertex lead (Cz)
Variable morphology (smooth, sinusoidal, arciform, spiky, or mu-like)
Variable reactivity to eye opening and alerting

common_confusions.why_confused: Both are central rhythms with similar morphology
common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Midline theta is 5–7 Hz and variable reactivity; mu rhythm is 8–10 Hz and blocks with movement
Midline theta is rhythmic and sustained; central spikes are isolated and epileptiform

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen at vertex (Cz); referential montages show field better

abret_exam_pearls: Midline theta rhythm (Ciganek rhythm) is most prominent at Cz, 5–7 Hz, with variable reactivity. It is a normal variant and should not be confused with mu rhythm (8–10 Hz, blocks with movement) or epileptiform activity.

report_language.how_to_describe: Midline theta rhythm (Ciganek rhythm), normal variant, maximal at vertex.
avoid_saying: Central slowing or Epileptiform activity when describing midline theta

name: Subclinical Rhythmic Electrographic Discharge in Adults (SREDA)
age_notes: Seen in people older than 50 years
morphology: Abrupt onset of mixed frequencies in delta and theta ranges that evolve into rhythmic pattern with sharp-contoured components 5–7 Hz
key_features: Evolves from mixed delta/theta to rhythmic 5–7 Hz
Lasts 20 s to a few minutes
Usually bilateral but may be asymmetric
May resemble subclinical seizure but typically no clinical correlation

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: SREDA typically has no clinical seizure correlation; seizure discharges show evolution and clinical correlation
SREDA is abrupt onset, evolves, and resolves; encephalopathy is sustained and correlates with clinical state

when_concerning: Controversial - may or may not correlate with clinical seizures

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages; parietal-posterior temporal maximum

abret_exam_pearls: SREDA is an uncommon pattern in people >50 years. It shows abrupt onset, evolution from mixed frequencies to rhythmic 5–7 Hz, and typically lacks clinical seizure correlation (though this is controversial).

report_language.how_to_describe: Subclinical rhythmic electrographic discharge in adults (SREDA), normal variant, maximal over parietal-posterior temporal regions.
avoid_saying: Seizure discharge when describing SREDA without clinical correlation

name: 14- and 6-Hz Positive Bursts (Ctenoids)
age_notes: Peak at age 13–14, decrease with increasing age
morphology: Short trains of arch-shaped waveforms with alternating positive spiky components and negative smooth rounded waveform resembling sleep spindle with sharp positive phase
key_features: Occurs during drowsiness and light sleep
Alternating positive spiky and negative smooth components
Mostly asynchronous, bilateral with shifting predominance
Better seen in referential montage (ear references)
May be enhanced in Reye's syndrome

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: 14&6 Hz positive bursts are posterior-temporal with positive spiky components; sleep spindles are central, 12–14 Hz, and lack positive spiky components
14&6 Hz positive bursts are rhythmic trains with positive spiky components; temporal spikes are isolated and epileptiform

filters: Standard filters adequate
Low HFF may attenuate 14 Hz component
montage_effects: Better seen in referential montage (ear references)
Posterior temporal maximum

abret_exam_pearls: 14&6 Hz positive bursts (ctenoids) are arch-shaped waveforms with positive spiky components, maximal posterior-temporally, peak at age 13–14. Better seen in referential montages. May be enhanced in Reye's syndrome.

report_language.how_to_describe: 14- and 6-Hz positive bursts (ctenoids), normal variant, maximal over posterior temporal regions.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform activity when describing 14&6 Hz positive bursts

name: 6-Hz Spike-and-Wave Bursts (Phantom Spike-and-Wave)
morphology: Brief bursts of subtle low-amplitude spikes followed by more prominent slow wave
key_features: Subtle low-amplitude spikes followed by prominent slow wave
Occurs during relaxed wakefulness and drowsiness
Disappears with deep sleep (unlike epileptiform spike-and-wave which persists)
Two types: FOLD (Female Occipital Low-amplitude Drowsiness) and WHAM (Wake High-amplitude Anterior Male)

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: 6 Hz spike-and-wave is low amplitude, brief, disappears in deep sleep; 3 Hz spike-and-wave is higher amplitude, sustained, persists in sleep, and associated with absence seizures
6 Hz spike-and-wave is low amplitude and disappears in deep sleep; epileptiform spike-and-wave persists in sleep and has clinical correlation

when_concerning: WHAM type more likely associated with seizures than FOLD type

filters: Standard filters adequate
Low sensitivity may hide low-amplitude spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
FOLD: occipital; WHAM: anterior
settings_sensitivity.sensitivity_notes: Standard sensitivity adequate; low-amplitude spikes may require higher sensitivity

abret_exam_pearls: 6 Hz spike-and-wave (phantom spike-and-wave) is low amplitude, brief, and disappears in deep sleep (unlike epileptiform spike-and-wave). FOLD type is benign; WHAM type may be more associated with seizures.

report_language.how_to_describe: 6-Hz spike-and-wave bursts (phantom spike-and-wave), normal variant, low amplitude.
avoid_saying: Epileptiform spike-and-wave when describing 6 Hz phantom spike-and-wave

name: Triphasic Waves
age_notes: Common in adults with metabolic encephalopathy
morphology: Three-phase waveform: negative-positive-negative

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Triphasic waves have three-phase morphology; FIRDA is monophasic rhythmic delta
Triphasic waves have characteristic three-phase morphology; diffuse slowing is polymorphic

when_concerning: Indicates metabolic encephalopathy, most commonly hepatic

filters: Standard filters adequate
High LFF may attenuate slow components
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Frontal-predominant distribution

abret_exam_pearls: Triphasic waves are highly characteristic of hepatic encephalopathy but can occur in other metabolic encephalopathies (uremic, hyperglycemic, lithium toxicity).
Triphasic waves are frontal-predominant and may be reactive to stimulation, distinguishing them from other encephalopathic patterns.

report_language.how_to_describe: Triphasic waves, frontal-predominant, consistent with metabolic encephalopathy.
avoid_saying: Pathognomonic of hepatic encephalopathy (can occur in other conditions)

name: Burst Suppression
age_notes: All ages, indicates severe cortical dysfunction
morphology: Alternating bursts of activity and suppression periods
key_features: Suppression periods are flat or near-flat

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Burst suppression has alternating bursts and suppression; diffuse slowing is continuous
Burst suppression has alternating bursts/suppression; alpha coma shows continuous alpha frequency

when_concerning: Indicates severe cortical dysfunction; persistent pattern has poor prognosis

filters: Standard filters adequate
High LFF may mask suppression periods
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Generalized distribution
settings_sensitivity.sensitivity_notes: Standard sensitivity adequate; may need higher sensitivity to see suppression periods clearly

abret_exam_pearls: Burst suppression indicates severe cortical dysfunction; persistent pattern has poor prognosis.
Burst suppression shows alternating bursts of activity and suppression periods, distinguishing it from continuous slowing patterns.

report_language.how_to_describe: Burst suppression pattern, indicating severe cortical dysfunction.
avoid_saying: Normal pattern (burst suppression is always abnormal)

name: Alpha Coma Pattern
age_notes: All ages, indicates severe brainstem dysfunction
morphology: Alpha frequency (8-13 Hz) but non-reactive

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Alpha coma is non-reactive and generalized; PDR is reactive and posterior
Alpha coma shows continuous alpha frequency; burst suppression has alternating bursts/suppression

when_concerning: Indicates severe brainstem dysfunction with very poor prognosis

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Generalized distribution

abret_exam_pearls: Alpha coma pattern shows alpha frequency but is non-reactive, indicating severe brainstem dysfunction with poor prognosis.
Alpha coma is generalized and non-reactive, distinguishing it from normal PDR which is posterior and reactive.

report_language.how_to_describe: Alpha coma pattern, non-reactive, indicating severe brainstem dysfunction.
avoid_saying: Normal alpha rhythm (alpha coma is always abnormal)

name: Periodic Sharp Wave Complexes (PSWCs)
morphology: Periodic sharp waves at 1-2 Hz, bilateral and synchronous

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: PSWCs are bilateral and synchronous; PLEDs are lateralized
PSWCs are 1-2 Hz and characteristic of CJD; GPDs are more variable

associated_with: Rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months, not years)
Cerebellar dysfunction (gait ataxia, limb incoordination, dysarthria)
Pyramidal and extrapyramidal signs (hyperreflexia, spasticity, rigidity, bradykinesia)
Death usually within 6-12 months of symptom onset
when_concerning: Highly characteristic of CJD, though not pathognomonic. Rapidly progressive dementia over weeks to months with myoclonus is CJD until proven otherwise.

filters: Standard filters adequate
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Bilateral, synchronous distribution

abret_exam_pearls: Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz are highly characteristic of CJD but can occur in other prion diseases.
PSWCs are bilateral and synchronous, distinguishing them from lateralized periodic patterns like PLEDs.
CJD is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia over weeks to months (not years), with myoclonus, cerebellar dysfunction, and PSWCs on EEG.
EEG may be normal or nonspecific early in CJD, becoming diagnostic later with PSWCs. Absence of PSWCs does not exclude CJD, especially early or in variant forms.
Myoclonus in CJD is often stimulus-sensitive (sound, touch, light) and correlates with PSWCs on EEG.

report_language.how_to_describe: Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz, bilateral and synchronous, highly characteristic of CJD.
avoid_saying: Pathognomonic of CJD (can occur in other prion diseases)

name: Extreme Delta Brush
age_notes: All ages, characteristic of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis
morphology: Rhythmic delta with superimposed beta activity

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Extreme delta brush has superimposed beta; diffuse slowing is polymorphic without beta
Extreme delta brush has superimposed beta; FIRDA is monophasic delta

when_concerning: Characteristic of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis

filters: Standard filters adequate
Low HFF may mask beta component
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
May be focal or generalized

abret_exam_pearls: Extreme delta brush (rhythmic delta with superimposed beta) is characteristic of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
Extreme delta brush has both slow (delta) and fast (beta) components, distinguishing it from other slowing patterns.

report_language.how_to_describe: Extreme delta brush pattern, rhythmic delta with superimposed beta, characteristic of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis.
avoid_saying: Pathognomonic of anti-NMDA (can occur in other autoimmune encephalitis)

name: Slow Spike-and-Wave (LGS Pattern)
morphology: Slow spike-and-wave complexes at 1.5-2.5 Hz

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Slow spike-and-wave is 1.5-2.5 Hz; 3 Hz spike-and-wave is 3 Hz. Slow spike-and-wave is characteristic of LGS.
Slow spike-and-wave has spike component; diffuse slowing is polymorphic without spikes

when_concerning: Indicates LGS, poor prognosis

filters: Standard filters adequate
High LFF may attenuate slow components
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Generalized distribution

abret_exam_pearls: Slow spike-and-wave (1.5-2.5 Hz) is characteristic of LGS - slower than typical 3 Hz spike-and-wave.
Slow spike-and-wave is most prominent during sleep - sleep recording is critical for LGS diagnosis.

report_language.how_to_describe: Slow spike-and-wave complexes at 1.5-2.5 Hz, generalized, characteristic of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.
avoid_saying: 3 Hz spike-and-wave when describing slow spike-and-wave (different frequency)

name: Polyspike-and-Wave
age_notes: Common in Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME), adolescents
morphology: Multiple spikes followed by slow wave
key_features: Multiple spikes (2-5+) followed by slow wave
More common in JME than pure 3 Hz spike-and-wave
May be activated by sleep deprivation and awakening

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: Polyspike-and-wave has multiple spikes (2-5+); 3 Hz spike-and-wave has single spike. Polyspike-and-wave is more common in JME.
Polyspike-and-wave has multiple spikes; slow spike-and-wave has single spike at slower frequency (1.5-2.5 Hz)

when_concerning: Indicates JME, requires lifelong treatment

filters: Standard filters adequate
Low HFF may mask multiple spikes
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Generalized distribution

abret_exam_pearls: Polyspike-and-wave (multiple spikes followed by slow wave) is more common in JME than pure 3 Hz spike-and-wave.
Polyspike-and-wave is activated by sleep deprivation and awakening - critical for JME diagnosis.

report_language.how_to_describe: Polyspike-and-wave complexes, generalized, symmetric, consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy.
avoid_saying: 3 Hz spike-and-wave when describing polyspike-and-wave (different morphology)

name: Generalized Paroxysmal Fast Activity (GPFA)
morphology: Generalized fast activity (beta/gamma range) in paroxysmal bursts

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: GPFA is paroxysmal bursts; beta rhythm is continuous. GPFA is most prominent during sleep and associated with LGS.
GPFA is faster (20-50 Hz) and paroxysmal; sleep spindles are 12-14 Hz and rhythmic

when_concerning: Indicates LGS, often associated with tonic seizures during sleep

filters: Standard filters adequate
Low HFF may mask fast activity
High HFF (70 Hz) recommended to see full frequency range
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages
Generalized distribution

abret_exam_pearls: GPFA (generalized paroxysmal fast activity) during sleep is highly characteristic of LGS.
GPFA is fast activity (20-50 Hz) in paroxysmal bursts, most prominent during sleep, often associated with tonic seizures.

report_language.how_to_describe: Generalized paroxysmal fast activity (GPFA) during sleep, characteristic of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.
avoid_saying: Beta rhythm when describing GPFA (different morphology and clinical significance)

name: Periodic Lateralized Epileptiform Discharges (PLEDs)
age_notes: All ages, most common in adults
morphology: Periodic sharp waves or spikes, lateralized to one hemisphere, occurring at regular intervals (typically 0.5–2 Hz)

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral); PSWCs are bilateral and synchronous
PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral); GPDs are generalized (bilateral)
PLEDs are periodic epileptiform discharges; focal slowing is continuous polymorphic delta without periodic spikes

when_concerning: Indicates acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction; requires clinical correlation for diagnosis

filters: Standard filters adequate (0.5–70 Hz)
High LFF may mask slow components
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages to show lateralization
Bipolar montages may show phase reversals at boundaries
settings_sensitivity.sensitivity_notes: Standard sensitivity adequate; may need adjustment for high-amplitude discharges

abret_exam_pearls: PLEDs are periodic, lateralized epileptiform discharges indicating acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction.
Most commonly seen in acute stroke, but also in HSE, brain tumors, trauma, and other acute structural lesions.
PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral), distinguishing them from bilateral periodic patterns like PSWCs (CJD) or GPDs.
May be ictal or interictal; clinical correlation is essential for interpretation.
Often seen in ICU settings; requires immediate notification of medical team.

report_language.how_to_describe: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) over the [hemisphere/region] at [frequency] Hz, consistent with acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction.
avoid_saying: Diagnostic of [specific condition] - PLEDs are seen in multiple conditions and require clinical correlation

name: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) EEG Pattern
age_notes: Onset in infancy, often at birth or within the first year of life (port-wine stain at birth, seizures typically begin in infancy)
morphology: Focal slowing and epileptiform discharges, background asymmetry
key_features: Corresponds to side of leptomeningeal angioma

common_confusions.how_to_distinguish: SWS shows focal slowing WITH epileptiform discharges and background asymmetry, corresponding to leptomeningeal angioma side
SWS is unilateral and focal; hypsarrhythmia is diffuse and multifocal

associated_with: Facial port-wine stain (trigeminal V1 distribution) - usually visible from birth
Early-onset focal seizures (often refractory) - typically begin in infancy, often before 1 year of age
Stroke-like episodes due to venous congestion
when_concerning: Early-onset seizures → worse prognosis
Progressive neurological deficits
EEG abnormalities correspond to side of leptomeningeal angioma

filters: Standard filters adequate
High LFF may mask focal slowing
montage_effects: Best seen in referential montages to show asymmetry
Bipolar montages may show phase reversals at boundaries

abret_exam_pearls: Sturge-Weber syndrome shows unilateral focal EEG abnormalities corresponding to the side of the leptomeningeal angioma.
Port-wine stain present at birth + seizures starting in infancy (within the first year of life) = Sturge-Weber syndrome (sporadic, not inherited).
Onset in infancy, often at birth or within the first year of life - port-wine stain at birth, seizures typically begin in infancy.
EEG shows focal abnormalities (slowing, spikes), not generalized patterns.
Early seizure control improves outcome in SWS.
Progressive worsening of EEG correlates with cortical injury.

report_language.how_to_describe: Unilateral focal slowing and epileptiform discharges over the [hemisphere], with background asymmetry, consistent with Sturge-Weber syndrome.
avoid_saying: Generalized pattern when describing SWS (it's focal/unilateral)
